Article Title: EU rejects Apple's call to scrap digital markets act
Article Text:
European Union flags (Pic credit: AP)

Apple cites security concerns

EU Stands firm on competition goals





The European Union firmly rejected Apple 's demand to repeal its landmark Digital Markets Act on Thursday, dismissing the tech giant's claims that the regulations compromise user security and calling for wholesale changes to enforcement.The European Commission said it had "absolutely no intention" to abandon the law after Apple submitted a formal request for the DMA to be "repealed while a more appropriate fit for purpose legislative instrument is put in place." EU digital affairs spokesman Thomas Regnier said the commission was "not surprised" by Apple's move, noting the company "has simply contested every little bit of the DMA since its entry into application. "Apple argued in its 25-page submission that the DMA has forced delays of new features in the EU, including live translation with AirPods and iPhone mirroring capabilities. The company claims it cannot implement these features without exposing user data to third parties, something it refuses to do for privacy reasons.The tech giant also raised concerns about increased security risks from mandatory app sideloading and alternative marketplaces, pointing to the availability of pornography and gambling apps that previously weren't allowed on iPhones.Apple says these changes expose EU users to "scams spread through fake banking apps, malware disguised as games, and third-party payment systems that overcharge them."The commission dismissed Apple's security arguments, with Regnier stating that "nothing in the DMA requires companies to lower their privacy standards, their security standards." Brussels maintains the law is necessary to prevent unfair market domination and level the playing field for Apple's competitors.The standoff intensifies as President Donald Trump seeks to pressure the EU over decisions affecting US Big Tech companies. Apple previously appealed a ‚Ç¨500 million DMA fine imposed in April and faces an additional ‚Ç¨1.8 billion penalty under separate EU competition rules.
Article Summary: EU rejects Apple's request to repeal its landmark Digital Markets Act. EU says it has "absolutely no intention" to abandon the law. Apple claims regulations compromise user security and calls for wholesale changes to enforcement. Apple previously appealed a ‚Ç¨500 million DMA fine imposed in April.

Microsoft has begun diversifying its AI technology by integrating a model from Anthropic into its 365 Copilot assistant. The software giant recently announced that it will start using the Anthropic model to answer some queries for its commercial clients. This move signals a shift in Microsoft's generative AI strategy, which has historically relied almost exclusively on OpenAI models for features across products like Bing and Windows. Microsoft is the lead investor in OpenAI, having committed more than $13 billion as part of its strategic partnership.Anthropic‚Äôs model is set to debut in Researcher, a Microsoft 365 Copilot agent that helps collect information, analyse it, and create reports.Employees in organisations that are part of Microsoft‚Äôs Frontier program, which gives early access to AI tools, can now opt to use Anthropic‚Äôs Claude Opus 4.1 reasoning model.This model is built to handle complex tasks and serves as an alternative to OpenAI‚Äôs offering within Researcher.In a blog post, Charles Lamanna, Microsoft‚Äôs president of business and industry Copilot, wrote:Corporate customers can now choose Anthropic‚Äôs Claude Sonnet 4 and Claude Opus 4.1 when creating custom AI agents using Microsoft‚Äôs Copilot Studio.However, administrators will need to enable Anthropic models before employees can access them. These models operate on Amazon and Google cloud platforms and are governed by Anthropic‚Äôs terms and conditions, Lamanna noted.Alongside adding models from outside partners, Microsoft has also begun testing MAI-1-preview, its own in-house large language model.OpenAI has been actively building partnerships with major players. In recent weeks, it announced plans to spend $300 billion with Oracle and signed a $10 billion deal with chip designer Broadcom. This week, Nvidia revealed it will invest up to $100 billion in OpenAI as part of a joint push to develop massive new data centres.While Microsoft and OpenAI continue to work closely, their relationship is shifting. Last year, Microsoft announced that GitHub Copilot Chat would also utilise models from Anthropic and Google, in addition to those from OpenAI.Founded in 2021 by former OpenAI executives, Anthropic was recently valued at $183 billion. Still, Microsoft remains the exclusive cloud provider for OpenAI‚Äôs programming interface that third-party apps depend on.

Article Title: Optus outage in Australia: What we know about the fatal triple-0 emergency call failures
Article Text:
Company knew of problems hours before resolution

Optus‚Äô previous failures raise accountability questions





Australia's second-largest telecommunications provider Optus is facing mounting pressure after a 13-hour emergency services outage led to four deaths and caused 600 triple-zero calls to fail across multiple states. The September 19 network failure has prompted government investigations and renewed calls for accountability from the embattled telco.The outage primarily affected South Australia, Western Australia, and the Northern Territory, with some impact also recorded in far western New South Wales near the SA border, according to Reuters reporting. CEO Stephen Rue confirmed that established processes were not followed during a network firewall upgrade that began at 12:30 AM Thursday and lasted until approximately 1:30 PM (local time).Four deaths have been linked to the incident, though South Australian police later clarified that an eight-week-old boy's death in Gawler West was "unlikely" to have been caused by the outage delay. A 68-year-old Adelaide woman and two men aged 74 and 49 in Perth remain connected to the emergency services failure.The Australian Broadcasting Company (ABC) reported that Optus received multiple customer complaints about the triple-zero failure as early as 9 AM Thursday, with five customers contacting the call center about the outage.However, these concerns were not properly escalated, and government authorities weren't informed until after the issue was resolved.Communications Minister Anika Wells expressed "unbelievable disappointment" that Australia was "here again so quickly," referencing a similar 2023 incident. The Australian Media and Communications Authority (ACMA) chair Nerida O'Loughlin revealed her agency wasn't notified until more than 10 hours after the outage began, contrary to standard protocols.This marks the second major triple-zero outage for Optus in less than two years. The company was fined A$12 million in 2023 for failing to provide emergency call services to thousands during a nationwide outage and subsequently failing to conduct required welfare checks.The telecommunications giant, owned by Singapore Telecommunications, has faced a series of crises including a 2022 cyberattack affecting 9.5 million Australians and the 2023 outage that led to former CEO Kelly Bayer Rosmarin's resignation. Current CEO Stephen Rue took over in November 2024.Prime Minister Anthony Albanese, speaking from New York, declined to say whether Rue should resign but indicated the government has "action at its disposal" pending investigation results. ACMA has launched a formal investigation, with Optus potentially facing fines exceeding $10 million and additional penalties.The company has promised full cooperation with all investigations while conducting its own internal review, with results to be made public.
Article Summary: 13-hour emergency services outage led to four deaths and 600 triple-zero calls to fail. Optus received multiple customer complaints about the outage as early as 9 AM Thursday. Government authorities weren't informed until after the issue was resolved. This marks the second major triple- zero outage for Optus in less than two years.

Article Title: Wipro founder Azim Premji replies to Karnataka CM on Bengaluru‚Äôs traffic problem: ‚ÄòThere is no silver bullet to resolve it, so we suggest ‚Ä¶‚Äô
Article Text:
wipro azim premji

To, Shri Siddaramaiah,

Hon'ble Chief Minister of Karnataka,

Vidhana Soudha,

Bangalore - 560 001

Sub: Re: Your Letter Regarding Traffic Congestion on Outer Ring Road (ORR)

Thank you for your letter dated September 19, 2025 and your kind recognition of Wipro's contributions to Karnataka. As stated in your letter, urgent and effective measures are indeed required for the traffic situation, particularly along the Outer Ring Road, being an export oriented economic hub.

That apart it will also be appreciated that our Sarjapur campus is a Special Economic Zone (SEZ) providing services to global customers, our contractual conditions mandate stringent, non-negotiable access control norms for governance and compliance.

Moreover, public vehicular movement through a private property would not be effective as a sustainable, long-term solution. Wipro nevertheless stands committed to partner with the Government of Karnataka to find a lasting solution for Bengaluru's mobility challenges. We believe a collaborative, data-driven approach will yield the most impactful results for our city.

Our team, led by Reshmi Shankar (email: reshmi.shankar@wipro.com), would be happy to engage with your officials to discuss the way forward at your earliest convenience.

Warm regards,

Yours sincerely,

AZIM PREMJI





Karnataka Chief Minister Siddaramaiah has written to Wipro founder Azim Premji requesting the IT giant to allow limited vehicular movement through its campus to help ease Bengaluru's notorious traffic congestion on the Outer Ring Road. In a letter dated September 19, Siddaramaiah specifically targeted the severe traffic bottleneck at Iblur junction along the ORR corridor, writing: "I wish to explore the possibility of allowing limited vehicular movement through the Wipro campus, subject to mutually agreed terms and necessary security considerations."Now, Wipro founder Azim Premji has responded to Karnataka Chief Minister Siddaramaiah letter. Permji has declined the request from the Karnataka government to part with a portion of the company‚Äôs Bengaluru campus land to ease traffic congestion in the city‚Äôs IT corridor. Premji said the decision was made in the best interests of the company and its employees, citing operational and security concerns.The Chief Minister cited preliminary assessments by traffic and urban mobility experts indicating that such a measure "could reduce congestion on adjoining stretches of the ORR by nearly 30 per cent, particularly during peak office hours." A detailed traffic simulation study by Bengaluru Traffic Police has projected even more promising results, suggesting that opening the Wipro‚ÄìEcoworld campus link road to the public could reduce travel time along the Sarjapur Road‚ÄìOuter Ring Road corridor by nearly 38%.Responding to the letter Premji said that while he understood the traffic challenges of the city, but Wipro could not compromise on its campus integrity and long‚Äëterm business needs.
Article Summary: Karnataka Chief Minister Siddaramaiah has written to Wipro founder Azim Premji. He asked the IT giant to allow limited vehicular movement through its campus to help ease Bengaluru's notorious traffic congestion on the Outer Ring Road. Article Title: Google‚Äôs ex-CEO Eric Schmidt warns US could lose AI race to China: We believed both countries were competing on equal footing but...

Ex-Google CEO Eric Schmidt recently warned that the US could lose AI race to China. "They're very focused on taking AI and applying it to everything‚Ä¶consumer apps, robots, and so forth," Schmidt said, adding US restrictions on semiconductor exports and China's limited access to capital have slowed the country‚Äôs pursuit of AGI ‚Äì Artificial General Intelligence.Artificial General Intelligence refers to a type of artificial intelligence that can perform a wide range of tasks at a human level of understanding. Unlike today‚Äôs AI systems, which are designed for specific tasks such as translation, image recognition, or playing games, AGI would have the ability to learn, reason, adapt, and apply knowledge across different domains ‚Äî much like humans do.During the conversation, Eric Schmidt drew parallel to China‚Äôs success in the EV sector, warning that companies are excelling in practical applications. He further warned that countries around the world are more likely to adopt Chinese models due to their open-source nature."China is competing with open weights and open training data. The U.S. is largely focused on closed weights, closed data," Schmidt said.When Chamath Palihapitiya asked Meta's open-source AI efforts, Schmidt responded saying smaller, more accessible models are being released, allowing AI to proliferate in controlled, Western-aligned ways.Previously, Eric Schmidt warns that the United States faces a critical energy shortage that could derail the artificial intelligence revolution, calling electricity, not semiconductors or funding, the primary constraint limiting AI development."AI's natural limit is electricity, not chips," Schmidt said in a LinkedIn post earlier this year, highlighting the infrastructure crisis facing Silicon Valley's race toward superintelligence.

Article Title: America‚Äôs largest business lobby may sue Trump administration on H-1B visa fee hike: ‚ÄòWe are examining the legal basis‚Äô
Article Text:
What US Chamber of Commerce spokesperson said

Trump administration increases H-1B visa application fee to $100,000





The US Chamber of Commerce is reportedly considering to file a lawsuit against the Trump administration after announcing a $100,000 annual fee on H-1B visa. The Chamber, the nation‚Äôs largest business group and one of Washington‚Äôs most influential lobbying organizations, has members like Amazon , Alphabet, Google , among others. It has so far avoided direct conflict with Trump in his second term. It even stayed out of recent legal battles over his tariffs.The group last went to court against Trump in 2020, when his administration suspended new nonimmigrant visas. Calling the policy ‚Äúbad for business,‚Äù the Chamber sued and won, with a federal court striking down the rules.Chamber spokesperson Matt Letourneau said in a statement that the group is ‚Äúexamining the legal basis for the proclamation.‚Äù‚ÄúWe continue to be inundated with member concerns and are communicating those concerns and questions directly to the administration,‚Äù Letourneau said.‚ÄúThere was tremendous concern about the prospect that the proclamation could be applied to current visa holders. We are appreciative of the administration‚Äôs ongoing clarifications about the scope of this action.‚ÄùLast week, Donald Trump signed an order introducing a $100,000 annual fee for H-1B visa applications. Explaining the move, Trump said ‚ÄúThe H-1B nonimmigrant visa program was created to bring temporary workers into the United States to perform additive, high-skilled functions, but it has been deliberately exploited to replace, rather than supplement, American workers with lower-paid, lower-skilled labour‚Äù.Anticipating the tech industry‚Äôs response to the changes, Trump said ‚ÄúI think they're going to be very happy‚Äù.

Article Title: ‚ÄòWould that be enough to convince you‚Äô: OpenAI CEO Sam Altman and father of quantum computing debate AI‚Äôs true test
Article Text:
A new test for AGI





OpenAI CEO Sam Altman and British physicist David Deutsch have agreed on a striking new test for artificial intelligence (AI) ‚Äì if an AI model could solve the mystery of quantum gravity ‚Äî and explain its reasoning ‚Äî it could be considered human-level smart. According to a Business Insider report, the exchange happened on Wednesday (September 24) in Berlin, where Altman visited Axel Springer‚Äôs headquarters to meet tech leaders and collect an award. During a fireside chat, publisher Mathias D√∂pfner asked Sam Altman about his favorite book ‚Äî Deutsch‚Äôs The Beginning of Infinity ‚Äî and then surprised him by patching the author in live from Oxford.Deutsch, often called the father of quantum computing, has long argued that brute-force training alone cannot produce true minds. He said real intelligence means creating knowledge, not just repeating or remixing it. ‚ÄúLarge language models can talk endlessly because they are trained on huge bodies of knowledge,‚Äù he explained. ‚ÄúIn my mind, genuine intelligence is the ability to create knowledge ‚Äî spot a problem, invent a solution, test it, and improve it as humans do. ‚ÄùSam Altman, smiling as Deutsch appeared on screen, asked a direct question: what would it take to convince him that an AI had reached real intelligence? Deutsch pointed to Einstein‚Äôs theory of relativity as an example of knowledge creation.‚ÄúWe know he created it because we know his story, what problems he was addressing, and why,‚Äù he said.Then Sam Altman offered a hypothetical: ‚ÄúIf a future model figured out quantum gravity and could tell you its story ‚Äî the problems it chose, the reasons it pursued them ‚Äî would that be enough to convince you?‚Äù‚ÄúI think it would, yes,‚Äù Deutsch replied.Altman agreed: ‚ÄúI agree to that as the test.‚Äù
Article Summary: OpenAI CEO Sam Altman and British physicist David Deutsch have agreed on a striking new test for artificial intelligence. If an AI model could solve the mystery of quantum gravity ‚Äî and explain its reasoning ‚Äî it could be considered human-level smart.

Article Title: Billionaire Silicon Valley investor says US' H-1B visa policy could backfire: ‚ÄòEngineers from Indian universities are‚Ä¶‚Äô
Article Text:
Tech companies hire for skills, not cost savings

Policy could drive innovation overseas





Billionaire Silicon Valley investor Michael Moritz, whose investments in Google PayPal , and other tech giants helped shape the modern internet, has sharply criticised President Donald Trump's $100,000 H-1B visa fee, warning that the policy will backfire and demonstrates the administration's fundamental misunderstanding of what drives American tech success.The policy, announced Friday through a presidential proclamation, imposes the steep fee on new H-1B visa applications starting September 21, representing a dramatic increase from current fees of $2,000 to $5,000. The administration also proposed overhauling the lottery system to prioritise higher-paid workers, with the Trump administration claiming the program has been "deliberately exploited to replace, rather than supplement, American workers. "The announcement triggered panic across Silicon Valley over the weekend, with companies including Amazon , Microsoft, and Google advising H-1B employees to return to the US before the Sunday deadline.Writing in the Financial Times, Moritz argued that Trump's "H-1B caper will backfire" because advances in technology make it easier for companies to move work overseas rather than bring foreign workers to America. The former Sequoia Capital partner warned that the policy shows "the fragile grasp the president and his acolytes have about why the US ‚Äî especially its technology sector‚Äîhas worked so well."The H-1B program currently allows 85,000 skilled foreign workers annually to work in the US for up to six years. Indian nationals account for 71% of approved visas, with the program heavily used by tech companies and IT consulting firms. Moritz noted that "engineers with undergraduate degrees from the better eastern Europe, Turkish and Indian universities are every bit as well qualified as their American counterparts," underlining the caliber of talent that could be affected by the policy changes.Moritz, who built his reputation investing in companies like Google, PayPal, LinkedIn, and YouTube during their early stages, dismissed Trump's claims that companies abuse the H-1B program to replace American workers with cheaper foreign labor. In his FT column, he emphasised that "large tech companies hire foreign nationals because they possess particular skills" and retain them "to perform tasks in areas where the US has labour shortages. "The investor argued that companies don't hire H-1B workers "to deprive Americans of jobs or for cost reasons," contradicting the administration's core justification for the fee increase. He noted that US companies are already "forbidden to discriminate against foreign workers doing the same jobs as American citizens" and must notify employees before hiring foreign workers.Trump's proclamation cited multiple examples of tech companies laying off American workers while simultaneously hiring thousands of H-1B visa holders. One unnamed software company was approved for over 5,000 H-1B workers in fiscal year 2025 while announcing layoffs totalling more than 15,000 employees, according to the White House. The administration argued this demonstrates the program is being used to replace rather than supplement American workers.Rather than protecting American jobs, Moritz warned the policy could push tech innovation abroad. He noted that skilled engineers from "better eastern Europe, Turkish and Indian universities are every bit as well qualified as their American counterparts," and much of their work "can be done as easily in Istanbul, Tallinn, Warsaw, Prague or Bengaluru as in San Francisco."The investor predicted that companies fearful of Trump's next move might change their policies, meaning "these foreign economies rather than the US will receive a shot in the arm." This would also "deprive America of a fresh generation of entrepreneurs since the most able of the H-1B visa holders often go on to start companies of their own."Moritz's warnings contrast sharply with support from some tech leaders, including Netflix co-founder Reed Hastings, who called the $100,000 fee "a great solution" that would ensure H-1B visas are "used just for very high-value jobs." However, most Silicon Valley executives have criticised the changes as harmful to innovation and startup growth.The policy has already created international ripple effects. India, which supplies 71% of H-1B visa holders, responded through its external affairs ministry that the fee would have "humanitarian consequences" and cause family disruptions. Indian Commerce Minister Piyush Goyal suggested Americans are "afraid of our talent."Moritz suggested the administration should instead expand the H-1B program, proposing to "double or triple the number of H-1B visas" and automatically offer citizenship to foreign nationals earning STEM PhDs from top American universities.He highlighted successful immigrant CEOs including Satya Nadella of Microsoft and Sundar Pichai of Google as examples of the program's benefits, noting in his FT piece: "Two of the finest chief executives in the US, Satya Nadella of Microsoft and Sundar Pichai of Google, are here because of the attitudes of prior administrations."

Article Title: After $100,000 annual fee, US plans to replace H-1B visa lottery system: What it may mean for Indian and foreign workers
Article Text:

US To Abandon H1-B Visa Lottery System, Trump Floats More Changes To Rules | Detailed Report

Impact on Indian IT professionals



Next steps and legal challenges







US President Donald Trump recently announced the fee hike for H-1B visa program. Last week, the US government increased the H-1B visa fee to $1,00,000 from $10,000. This annual fee applies to all the fresh H-1B visa applications. Now, days after imposing the new fee, the Trump administration has introduced a new proposal which is aimed at revamping the H-1B visa program. As reported by Reuters, the new proposal of the Trump administration aims to scrap the the long‚Äëstanding lottery system and replace it with a weighted selection process that favours higher‚Äëskilled and higher‚Äëpaid applicants.Presently, the H-1B program is capped at 85,000 visas annually and it uses a random lottery when the application exceed demand. Under the new rules, the Department of Homeland Security (DHS) proposes a wage‚Äëbased ranking system, giving preference to applicants with advanced degrees, specialized skills, and higher salary offers.As per the Reuters report, the official suggests that this change will make sure that the visas go to the ‚Äúthe best and brightest‚Äù while still allowing employers to hire foreign workers at all wage levels. The administration claims that it has framed the reform in order to curb the ‚Äòabuse‚Äô of the system done by outsourcing firms.The changes made to the H-1B visa system could have a critical impact on the Indian technology workers, who make up the largest share of H-1B recipients. While highly paid engineers and specialists may benefit, entry‚Äëlevel workers and outsourcing companies that rely on bulk visa applications could face reduced opportunities.Experts suggest that this new rule could reshape the global IT services market and will push the companies to expand operations in India or other regions of access to US visa becomes restricted.This new proposed rule of the Trump administration will now undergo a public comment period before it is finalised. The legal challenges are expected as the earlier attempt to reform the H-1B visa system have faced pushback in the US courts. If implemented, the reforms ‚Äî combined with the new $100,000 annual fee ‚Äî would mark one of the most dramatic shifts in U.S. skilled immigration policy in decades, with ripple effects across the global technology and outsourcing industries.

Article Title: Samsung subsidiary Harman completes acquisition of Bowers & Wilkins, Denon and other audio brands from Apple's legal rival Masimo
Article Text: Samsung subsidiary Harman International has completed its $350 million acquisition of premium audio brands Bowers & Wilkins, Denon, Marantz, and Polk Audio from Masimo Corporation, Apple 's legal adversary in ongoing smartwatch patent disputes.The deal transfers eight distinguished audio brands from Masimo's Sound United division to Samsung's audio empire: Bowers & Wilkins, Denon, Marantz, Definitive Technology, Polk Audio, HEOS, Class√©, and Boston Acoustics. These premium names now join Samsung's existing stable of audio brands including JBL and Harman Kardon, acquired when the tech giant purchased Harman for $8 billion in 2016.Masimo Corporation, best known for its medical device technology, became a household name in tech circles after launching aggressive patent litigation against Apple over smartwatch pulse oximetry features. The company successfully forced Apple to disable blood oxygen monitoring on Apple Watches sold in the US, creating a bitter legal feud that continues to unfold.Sound United, formerly Masimo Corporation's consumer audio division, will operate as a standalone Strategic Business Unit within Harman's Lifestyle Division. This structure ensures each brand maintains its heritage and customer identity while leveraging Harman's global resources and reach."Sound United's impressive roster of brands aligns perfectly with Harman's values of innovation, quality, and sound excellence," said Dave Rogers, President of Harman's Lifestyle Division. The acquisition allows Harman to broaden its offerings across home audio systems, headphones, amplifiers, AV receivers, and car audio solutions.The completed sale allows Masimo to shed its consumer audio division and concentrate resources on its core medical device business and its high-stakes legal battle with Apple. The company launched a lawsuit against US Customs and Border Protection in August 2025, seeking to maintain import restrictions on certain Apple Watch models.
Article Summary: Harman International has completed its $350 million acquisition of premium audio brands Bowers & Wilkins, Denon, Marantz, and Polk Audio. These premium names now join Samsung's existing stable of audio brands including JBL and Harman Kardon.
